column1: ASIC 200 Global Issues in the Arts and Sciences
column8: Second year standing in FoA of FoS; enrolment restricted to 45 FoS students
column9: Selected global issues explored through the methodologies and perspectives of both the physical and life sciences and the humanities and social sciences.

column8: Second-year standing
column9: Sustainability examined from scientific, economic, and societal perspectives.

column8: One of: MATH 101,103,105,121; AND one of PHYS 101, 106,107,117,131,157; AND one of APSC 160, CPSC 103,110, DSCI 100, EOSC 211
column9: The meteorology of hydro, wind, and solar power. Atmospheric processes affecting renewable energy on global, regional & local weather scales.

column1: ATSC 413: Forest Fire Weather and Climate
column6: New course for Fall 2023; does not appear to be full
column8: One of ATSC 201, GEOS 200
column9: New for Fall 2023; ATSC 413 is designed to educate highly qualified personnel with the technical skill-set to forecast forest-fire weather, to anticipate evolution of fire hazards associated with a changing climate, and to advise on sustainable fire-mitigation policies.  A large portion of this new course is on synoptics (i.e., weather forecasting).  Students in ATSC 413 will learn how to interpret, communicate, and apply modern numerical weather prediction (NWP)-based forecasting (Bauer et al 2015, Stuart et al, 2022) to fire-weather issues.

column8: provided by Carl Michal

column8: provided by Carl Michal
provided by Carl Michal
provided by Carl Michal
Not open to students who have taken Biology 11 or 12 in high school
column9: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems.
column10: Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB).

column8: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111
column9: This course serves ~2000 students per year; it is required for Life Sciences students; it is a pre-req for many BIOL and MICB courses

column1: BIOL 155 Human Biology: Physiology & Introductory Anatomy
column8: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, 110, 111; One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111
column9: Foundational for planetary / human health.  Prep for health sciences professional degrees; focus is to study human biology and understand how its physical structure and physiological chnages enable the human body to adapt to varying environmental challenges

column1: BIOL 180: Thinking Like a Life Scientist
column8: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12; BIOL 111
column9: Foundational for planetary / human health. Aims to teach you to think scientifically about the research process, communicate science to a general audience, and work collaboratively to reach a shared goal

column1: BIOL 209 Biodiversity of Algae, Fungi and Bryophytes
column8: One of: BIOL 121, SCIE 001; OR, 8 transfer credits of first year biology
column9: Biodiversity focus

column8: One of: BIOL 121; SCIE 001
column9: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists:
column10: Calendar indicates many sections blocked

column8: BIOL 230; "Non-biology students interested in taking these courses are to register themselves on the waitlist and will be considered after all biology students are successfully registered into the course from the waitlist."
column9: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month.
column10: BIOL 230 is prereq

column8: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230; FRST 201; GEOB 207; GEOS 207
column9: The units of biodiversity, from genes to ecosystems, how they are structured in space, and their importance to human well-being and ecosystem health.
column10: Pre-reqs: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOB 207, GEOS 207.
column11: Pre-reqs: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOB 207, GEOS 207.

column8: Either BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, 103, 105, 121 OR SCIE 001
column9: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis.

column8: One of BIOL 300 or STAT 200
column9: Introduction to uses of mathematics in the biological sciences; experimental design and modelling of biological processes.

column8: BIOL 230; "Non-biology students interested in taking these courses are to register themselves on the waitlist and will be considered after all biology students are successfully registered into the course from the waitlist."
Restricted to students in year 3 or 4
column9: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students.

column1: BIOL 347 Principles & Methodology in Biological Research
column9: A course on contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; and seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology.

column6: New for Fall 2023; appears to be blocked from registration by BIOL program; seats are remaining
column8: New for Fall 2023? Doesn't appear to have a lab; A minimum of 3rd year standing
column9: New for Fall 2023?
Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds.

The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year.
column10: Restricted to 3/4 year

column8: Consult Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List; One of BIOL 230; FRST 201
column9: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives.
column10: BIOL 230 or FRST 201 prereq

column8: Restricted to students in year >=4
column9: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication.
column10: Blocked; have to have a fourth year standing

column9: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society.
column10: Blocked; lots of prereqs

column9: Ecology, function, history and conservation of tropical systems. Focus on ecological and evolutionary principles using tropical landscapes as a geographic template. Assessment of factors that make tropical systems vulnerable to degradation. Research project development using analysis of tropical ecology literature.

Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles. Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia.

column1: BIOL 465 Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
column9: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity.

column1: CHEM 121 Structure and Bonding in Chemistry

column9: Introduction to structure, composition and chemical processes occurring in Earth's atmosphere, including interactions with solar radiation, stratospheric ozone layer, photochemical smog and acid rain.
column10: Prereq - Chem 123, 130, CHBE 220; Third Year standing

column1: CHEM 341 Global Challenges: A Chemical Perspective
column9: Importance of chemistry in society. Detailed case studies drawn from modern chemistry: human health, energy, commodity chemicals, materials, green chemistry, agriculture.
column10: Series of second year Chem prereqs

column8: Open to all students with second year or higher standing
column9: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies.
column10: Open to students in 2nd year or higher

column9: Community-engaged climate action projects; skill building for climate action.

column1: ENVR 300 Introduction to Research in Environmental Science
column8: Open to all students with 3rd year or higher standing in the Faculty of Science
column9: Environmental research. Students investigate research methodologies and reporting in a range of scientific disciplines and fields.
column10: Open to students in 3rd year or higher

column8: 3rd year standing and approval from the Climate STudies and Action Certificate Program Administrator
column9: Community-engaged climate action projects; skill building for climate action.
column10: Open to students in 3rd year or higher

column1: ENVR 400 Community Project in Environmental Science
column8: ENVR 300
column9: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449.
column10: Prereq ENVR 300

column8: 4th year standing in BSC, BASC or related programs
column9: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use. Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use. Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives.
column10: 4th year standing in BSc or BA programs

column1: ENVR 420 Ecohydrology of Watersheds and Water Systems
column9: Analysis of water resources from a water-in-ecosystem perspective. Application to natural, managed, and urban systems, considering ecological interactions with hydrological processes. Exploration of biogeochemical processes related to water quality, and human impacts on water resources.

Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions.
column10: Prereqs ENVR 300; BIOL 230; or 4th year standing in BSCN program

column1: ENVR 440 Analytical Methods in Sustainability Science
column8: One of ENVR 200, ASIC 220, SCIE 220, GEOG 211; 3rd year standing
column9: Sustainability analysis through a series of case studies. Example approaches include cost-benefit analysis, trade-offs analysis, and life-cycle analysis. Active learning in a computer lab using real-world data.

column1: EOSC 110 The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet
column9: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes. Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.)
column10: Consult credit exclusion list

column1: EOSC 112 The Fluid Earth: Atmosphere and Ocean
column9: Introduction to processes in ocean and atmosphere. Heat, current, winds, clouds, marine life, resources. Effects of coupling, climate change, pollution. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list, within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)
column10: Consult credit exclusion list

column1: EOSC 212 Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences.
column9: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences. Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature.
column10: Second year standing in APSC or SCIE

column9: Introduction to diversity of marine habitats and ecosystems; hydrothermal vent, intertidal, coral reef, estuarine, deep sea, and polar ecosystems; impacts of ecosystem change; evolution of ocean plankton; invasive species; climate change; pollution.
column10: Pre-reqs: One of SCIE 001, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154.

column1: EOSC 310 The Earth and the Solar System

column9: Theories of storage and movement of water within groundwater systems; Groundwater-surface water interaction; Role of groundwater systems in watershed management and regulating the environmental impacts of global change; Groundwater sustainability; Impacts of climate & land use changes on groundwater resources

column1: EOSC 326 Earth and Life Through Time

column9: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global environmental and climate change.
column10: Pre-reqs: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

column1: EOSC 372 Introductory Oceanography: Circulation and Plankton
column9: Physical and chemical processes and their controls on the distribution of plankton in the ocean.
column10: Pre-reqs: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

column1: EOSC 373 Introductory Oceanography: Climate and Ecosystems
column9: Physical, chemical, and biological processes in the ocean and their interaction with climate and marine food-webs.
column10: Pre-req EOSC 372

column1: EOSC 428 Field Techniques in Groundwater Hydrology

column9: Local climate time series collection and analysis. Retrieval and analysis of online climate data and model output.

A quantitative examination of processes regulating the abundance, distribution and production of phytoplankton, zooplankton, microbes and fish. Controls of primary and secondary production, ecosystem dynamics and foodwebs.

column1: EOSC 472 Chemical Oceanography and Marine Geochemistry
column9: Controls on chemical composition and elemental distributions in seawater and marine sediments (including nutrient elements, dissolved gases, the carbonate system, marine organic matter, and trace metals); solution chemistry of seawater; isotopic tracers of rates and dates in marine systems; geochemical balance in the oceans.

An interdisciplinary study of pollution, with examples drawn from coastal and oceanic environments, including areas of local interest. Intended for third and fourth year students with a background in the sciences.
column10: 3rd year standing; interdsciplinary

column9: An introduction to the ecology and management of freshwater and marine fisheries. Topics include: population dynamics, species interactions, communities, environmental influences, stock assessment, economics and sociology of fisheries. Laboratories will consist of numerical analyses and simulations.

column1: EOSC 532 Field Laboratory in Groundwater Hydrology
FISH 500 Issues in Fisheries Research: Seminars - Fisheries Management
FISH 501 Issues in Fisheries Research: Ecosystem Modelling
FISH 504 Quantitative Analysis of Fisheries I
FISH 505 Quantitative Analysis of Fisheries II
FISH 507 Grand Challenges in Ocean Leadership
FISH 520 Fisheries Conservation, Governance, and Evaluation
ISCI 360 Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
column9: Application of systems science encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems approaches to study regional sustainability.
column10: 3rd year standing

column1: ISCI 361 Field Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
column9: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate a selected region of the world. Course location will vary; fee payable prior to field course.

column1: ISCI 461 Comparative Field Research Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
column9: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate, analyze and research two unique regions of the world. Course location may vary; course location must be different than ISCI 361; fee payable prior to field course.

column1: MATH 102 Differential Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
MRNE 437 Population and Community Ecology of Marine Organisms
column9: Emphasis on interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physiochemical environment, and on biological diversity.
The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change.
column10: online; Pre-reqs: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158; or (b) SCIE 001

column9: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year.

column1: RES 502 Master's Seminar on Resources and Environment
column9: Environment and resource management goals and issues.
Critical analysis of harms and benefits, and anticipation of global technological innovations, as they interact with social behaviour.
Fostering sustainable management of ecosystem-based activities, for the competing and complementary ends of sustaining and enhancing human well-being and protecting biodiversity.
Dynamics of environmental issues across temporal and spatial scales using disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches to integrating sociological, cultural, and ecological perspectives.

column1: RES 520 Climate Change: Science, Technology and Sustainable Development
column9: Interdisciplinary science of climate change and its impacts; options for mitigation and adaptation.

column1: SCIE 420 Sustainability for Community and the World
column9: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations.
column10: Pre-reqs: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW 386, LFS 250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, PSYC 421, SCIE 120, SCIE 320. (Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.)
